text: Judy Garland’s “Get Happy” plays as the camera surfs thro the streets of Laguna Beach. It’s another perfect day. Su shines through the palm trees, birds chirp and the ocean washes up on the shore in the distance. We focus in on a VOLVO SUV as it turns into a parking lot.

JEN, poised and put together, pulls her SUV into a parkin spot. She checks her eye make-up in the mirror. It’s smud from crying. She wipes the runny mascara off her cheek, p on some lipstick and gathers herself. INT. JEN’S VOLVO - CONTINUOUS The song “Paralyzed” by the HARDCORE GERMAN DEATH METAL b Caliban blasts on Jen’s stereo.
Jen, unfazed by the music, blots her lipstick on a napkin She takes a deep breath, grabs her purse and exits the ca
Jen walks up a beautifully gardened pathway to a charming bluffside GAZEBO. A sign attached to the gazebo’s entranc reads “Friends of Heaven.”

Jen, uncomfortable, heads to an underwhelming snack table WORN-OUT-LOOKING PEOPLE gather. She pours herself coffee, takes a sip and spits it right back into her cup. JUDY approaches, smiling. She exudes warmth, a touch of hippy just a sliver of sadness.
(to Judy) Skip the coffee. It’s awful.
I made it.
I’m sorry.
I’m kidding. It’s terrible. (extends her hand) I’m Judy.
(hesitantly shakes it Jen.
Beautiful day, right?
(over it) It always is.
I love your blouse. It’s a good color for you. Most people don’t know their palate. They’11 wear a spring when they’re a fall but you know you’re a winter and that’s huge.
Thanks.
(playful) You come to this group often?
My first time.
Me too. (then) I’11 leave you alone. (then) But sorry, hope this isn’t weird... you do real estate, right? I feel like I’ve seen your picture on like a bus bench. You and a cute gay guy.
Yeah, that’s me. And Christopher, who does not think he looks gay in that picture.
Oh, I didn’t mean it in a bad way. Gay is a beautiful thing. Who doesn’t want a gay real estate agent?
Which bench did you see?
The one where you’re like -- Judy puts her hands on her hips and fake smiles.
No, I meant, I guess I meant where do you live?
Sorry. Newport.
(surprised) You live in Newport?
Yeah, I don’t think I belong there either.
Not belonging there is a good thing. Jen grabs a business card from her purse and hands it to Judy. JEN (CONT’D) If you ever need a realtor.
I might, thank you. Sorry, I hope this isn’t weird but... can I... hug you?
-No.
Okay.
I don’t really like to be touched.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 4, 3/20/18
That’s okay. Sorry, I’m just, I’ma hugger and I thought you kinda look like you need a hug.
Do I?
Well, you’re here.
I’m really fine.

Jen, in an ANGRY RAGE, throws a decorative side table at CHRISTOPHER, her church-going-gay real estate partner. He lunges out of the way, as the table shatters a sliding gl door. Their clients, a RICH ORANGE COUNTY COUPLE, look on fear.

Jen and Judy sit in a circle of chairs with PASTOR WAYNE, kind, older man with a bad toupee, KYLE, a middle-aged feelings-eater, YOLANDA, a religious older black woman, WENDY, a sweet lesbian, and LINDA, dead inside.
Looks like we have some new people today. He looks at Jen, expectantly.
That’s okay.

Alright. Well, welcome to Friends of Heaven. I’m Pastor Wayne. As some of you know, I like to start out our grief circle by talking about a loss I lived through, that got me into this work. Nice haircut, Wendy. Wendy smiles.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 5. 3/20/18 PASTOR WAYNE (CONT’D) My aunt fell down a flight of stairs and cracked her head open and bled out as her five-year-old son watched. And I was the one who asked her to get me a soda from the basement. So, I live with that. And that’s a little something about me.
Oh my god.
I appreciate that. Is there a loss you’ve had that you’d like to share with us today?
I... um, I lost my fiancé eight weeks ago. (tearing up) I’m Judy.
Hi, Judy.
Hi. (beat) It was really sudden. One minute we were eating dinner and then the next, he was gone.
Judy, in a pretty summer dress, is doubled over, crying n to a NURSE.
I’m sorry.
(through messy tears) Thank you.
All eyes on Judy.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 6. 3/20/18
Heart attack?
(nods) He was forty-nine.
(sympathetic) That sucks.
(through messy tears) Thank you.
Thank you for sharing that. Does anyone else new want to share about a loss they’re living with? Everyone looks at Jen.
No.
At your own pace.
(sotto, to Jen) I didn’t talk my first week either.
So, last week we started talking about the “F word.” Jen and Judy exchange a confused look.

Forgiveness. Forgiveness can be very difficult, and it can take time, even a lifetime, but it’s a way through. Sometimes we need to forgive the person who passed, a doctor maybe, an EMT who arrived too late, God, maybe ourselves. But, no matter what the circumstances, everyone is deserving of forgiveness.
You really think that?
Jesus thought that.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 7. 3/20/18
Amen.
--How do you forgive someone for hitting your husband with their car, then driving away and leaving him to bleed to death on the side of a road? The room goes quiet as everyone looks at Jen.
All eyes still on Jen.
No, that’s it. I don’t really want to get into it, I just -- someone else can go.
The group gives Judy supportive looks.

(choking back tears) It feels like such a deep ache. Not just for how much I miss him, but for the things I won’t even get to miss. We were three months away from our wedding. I have my dream dress hanging in my closet. It’s a 1950’s vintage princess scoop neck.
Oh, pretty.
Yeah, it fits really well.
I miss my husband so much sometimes I think I’1ll be sick.
These things take time.
It’s been eighteen years.
(to herself) Jesus Christ.
Why do people have to die?

And why do we have to forgive? (then, re: Jen) She’s supposed to forgive a hit and run driver? I’m supposed to forgive cancer? Cancer left my daughter without a mom. Fuck cancer. Cancer's a big fat crooked dick. Sorry, Pastor.
(uncomfortable) Alright.
(starts to cry When does the pain go away?
It will.
Or it won’t.

Is this -- I’m sorry -- is this supposed to be making me feel better? Because this is -- you’re all very sad. And I’m really truly sorry, but I have enough of my own misery. I don’t have room for anyone else’s.
Of course, I know it can feel that way. It's okay that you're feeling whatever you're feeling: sad, angry, defensive --
I’m not defensive, I’m just -- I’m tired.
I’m tired too.
(to Jen) Can you tell us about that?  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 9. 3/20/18

I just haven’t been sleeping. I was never a good sleeper, but since Ted died, I don’t sleep. Not naturally, anyway. And I don’t want to take pills, I’m not apills person. I have two kids, two boys who need me and I’m not gonna be one of those Xanax Ambien Zombie Moms. Linda, dead-faced, gives Jen a knowing look.
Nights are really hard.
Yeah.
Mornings suck too.
Yeah. Well, they’re okay for like two seconds --
-- But then you remember.
Exactly.
And it’s like you’re living ina recurring nightmare -- but you can’t wake up, because you are awake.
(re: Judy) She gets it.
I get it. Jen and Judy share her a small smile. Two peas in a sad, tired pod.
The group is dispersing. As Jen heads out, Judy stops her
I’m up all night. Judy hands Jen a small piece of paper.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 10. 3/20/18
Feel free to call me and we can not sleep together.
Jen enters a beach chic office as Christopher, in a neck brace, whips around in his desk chair.
(startled) Jesus in heaven! Jen, you know I’m still a little on edge.
I told you I’m sorry.
Yes, I got the orchid, thank you.
I went. To that grief group.
You did? Pastor Wayne there?
He was.
He ask about me? J.K. I’m glad you went. Did it help?
Yeah, I’m completely better.
Is sarcasm one of the stages of grief?
Yeah, it’s right after throwing shit at your business partner when they say “maybe you just should be grateful for the time you had with your dead husband.”

I don’t think that’s a real stage. (off her look) Jen, I was just trying to help you. And, frankly, after thirteen years, it’s hurtful you think of me as just your “business partner.”  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 11. 3/20/18
You know what I meant.
You know I love you, right? You’re like family to me.
You don’t like your family.
You know what I meant.
Any word from Vista Glen? The repair estimate come in?
Yeah. Eighty-five-hundred. The doors were custom.
Fine, we’ll make it up when we sell it.
We won’t actually. They dropped us. And so did Valley Drive. When they heard what happened at Vista Glen.
Fuck. Fuck.
Listen, Jenny, you’ve been through a tragic loss, just a total nightmare. Maybe you should think about taking some time off --
(sharp) I don’t want to take any fucking time off!
(a little scared) Okay!
Sorry. (then) I’1l find us a new listing. A good one. I promise. I’ll make it up to you.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 12. 3/20/18
Okay. You do that. (beat) And you let me know if there’s anything I can do for you and the kids.
Wanna come over for dinner Saturday?
Can’t this weekend. The boys and I are in Palm Springs. But let’s raincheck that for sure.
A pastel-painted rec room filled with ELDERLY PEOPLE play cards, reading, and staring out the window. Judy approach ABE, 86, sharper than the rest.
Abe, the nurse says you’re not taking your statins. She asked me to see what’s going on. Not that I need an excuse to talk to the hottest guy in here.
That’s not saying a lot. If you consider the other contestants.
What’s going on? Why aren’t you taking them?
I don’t need ‘em. It’s not a concern. I survived the Holocaust, high cholesterol doesn’t really move the needle for me. What I really need is some reefer.
What? (sotto) You already went through what I gave you?
What else am I doing?
You could be doing a lot. There’s a bridge tournament on Tuesdays, I lead a chair yoga class every morning --  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 13. 3/20/18
I don’t have the knees for yoga.
It’s very low impact.
I just don’t want to.
Okay, I’1ll get some pot for you.
Thank you.
(presents pill cup) But you have to take this for me. Because I love you. And I can’t deal with losing anyone else right now... She starts to choke backs tears.
Hey, hey, now. Judy, don’t cry, come on. Don’t cry. I’1l take ‘em. I’11 take ‘em.
I’m sorry... I’m just, I think I’m feeling a little alone right now.
Right now, of course. I understand. (takes her hand) You know, after Lydia died, I never thought I'd meet anyone or love anyone again. But I was wrong, right?
Yeah.
Because then I met Diane.
Right, you’re right. (beat) But then Diane died.
That’s true.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 14. 3/20/18 INT. JEN’S HOUSE - EVENING Jen’s at the door. KAREN, an uptight Orange County mom, h her a casserole.
So, you just heat it up at three hundred and leave it in for thirty-five minutes.
Thanks, Karen. But you really don’t have to keep --
It’s my take on Mexican lasagna.
(curt) Great.
It’s nothing. We just don’t want you to think you’re alone. Jeff and I are here for you. If you ever want to talk.
Thanks.
Just can’t imagine what you’re going through.
Well, it’s like if Jeff was hit by acar and died. Suddenly. And violently.
Right. (then, re: casserole) Well, you get that dish back to me whenever you can. No rush -- Jen shuts the door in her face.
Jen eats the casserole with her sons, CHARLIE, 14, all ed and HENRY, 9, all soft.
Why are there raisins in this?  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 15. 3/20/18
I honestly don’t know.
I like it.
I’m sick of other people’s food.
Me too.
I miss Dad’s cooking.
Me too.
It’s so not fair.
Which part?
Why did our dad have to die? Why didn’t Tyler’s dad die? Rick. That guy’s a douche. Jen can’t help but nod in agreement.
I like Rick.
A WHITE GUY IN A TURBAN hands Judy a take-out container.
Namaste.
Thanks, Glen. INT. HENRY’S BEDROOM - EVENING Jen tucks Henry in. She turns off a lamp, and switches on night light.
You have to wait ‘til I’m asleep. All the way asleep.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 16. 3/20/18
I know, Boop.
Mommy, I don’t want to go to school tomorrow.
No kidding.
I want to go to work with you.
I know, Hen, but we can’t do that anymore. It’s been three months. We gotta go back to normal.
(getting worked up) But I want to be with you.
I know. I know you do. (then) You know, honey, what happened to your dad was an accident.
As far as we know.
(yelling) Charlie, please! (then, to Henry) What happened to your dad was a freak accident.
Yeah.
And nothing like that is going to happen to me. I’m going to be fine. I promise. So, you don’t have to worry, okay?
I’m not worried something is going to happen to you.
(not buying it) No? Then what are you worried about?  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 17. 3/20/18 Henry takes Jen’s hand in his as he closes his eyes.

I just don’t want you to be alone. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM - A LITTLE LATER Jen ugly sobs under the covers. It’s a big master bedroom she seems small in it. She gets up, muffling her crying w a pillow, as she crosses into the bathroom. She pees, sti crying into a pillow. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM - A LITTLE LATER We see Jen go through her nightly rituals: -She pumps full speed on the Elliptical, drenched in swea -She finishes a work e-mail on her laptop. She types: “,..perfect time to list your house. It’s a seller’s mark -She watches an old movie on TV, dressed in her husband's pajamas, her wet hair in a towel. -She looks at her husband’s side of the bed. -She stares at the ceiling fan spinning. Her bedside cloc reads: 12:06. Then, at a loss, she takes out Judy's number.
INT. JUDY’S BEDROOM - SAME TIME Judy, wide awake, lays in the dark, watching Oprah’s SuperSoul Sunday. Her phone rings, she answers and we intercut the following conversation:
Hello?
Hi... it's Jen... from the grief group.
(perks up) Hiiii.
Sorry, I don't know why I called you.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 18. 3/20/18
It’s okay, I said you could.
Is it too late?
Yeah, I’m totally asleep.
Me too. A beat.
You in bed?
Yeah.
(suggestively) What are you wearing?
(taken aback) What?
What are you wearing?
My husband's sweatpants and a T-shirt he got for running a 5K for psoriasis.
Slower.
You're a weird person, Judy.

Thank you. (then) Did your husband like running? Or did he just hate psoriasis? Jen goes silent. JUDY (CONT’D) Sorry, you don’t have to talk about him if you don’t want to.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 19. 3/20/18 A long beat.
He liked running. But he came to it later. He started when he was forty -- the Couch To 5K app.
What made him start?
He was getting doughy.
Yeah, guys get that middle aged man puff.
Oh, he was getting a full on beer belly. But he also getting beer neck.
Beer neck!
I got on him a little, ‘cause he was lazy, and I was physically repulsed by him --
You weren’t.
(she was) Okay.
Go on.
So... he started running. Got really into it. He was training for the Maui marathon. I was proud of him. He was in the best shape of his life when the car hit him.
I’m so sorry.
Yeah. (then, listening) Are you eating something?  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 20. 3/20/18

It’s a donut. (takes a bite) And honestly, I feel really good about it. INT. JEN’S KITCHEN / JUDY’S BEDROOM - A LITTLE LATER Jen eats an Entenmann’s donut at her kitchen island, stil the phone with Judy. The microwave clock reads 12:47.
..-.Ted was always a gifted writer, even then. And he was the only guy in my dorm who listened to Ani DiFranco.
I love Ani.
She’s not for me, but I liked that about him. (beat, then) I haven’t really talked about him much since he died.
We can stop. I don’t mean to pry --
No... it’s, um, it’s nice. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM / JUDY’S BEDROOM - LATER Jen lays sideways across her bed, still on the phone with Judy. Her bedside clock reads 2:38.
Did you get it? Judy looks at a photo on her phone.
Is that him?
No, that’s my other husband.
Oh, you have another one? You’re fine.
Yeah, but if something happens to him...  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 21. 3/20/18 They laugh. JEN (CONT’D) It feels weird to be laughing.
I think it’s okay.
Okay.
When do you think it’s okay to masturbate again? (then, off Jen’s silence) Sorry, I don’t have any one else to ask.
No, yeah, I don’t know the answer to that. (then) Not now? I guess.
I'll google it. Jen yawns. JUDY (CONT’D) (re: yawn) I heard that. You should ride that wave and go to sleep.
No, I wanna see a photo of Steve.

I’d have to look. Jen’s phone dings. Judy sent ten photos. JUDY (CONT’D) Found some. Jen scrolls through the pics. Steve is a cute, clean cut, well-dressed man. Jen stops on a photo of Steve standing front of a beautiful, expensive looking Newport Beach hou
Is that your house?
Yeah.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot"
Wow. (a beat, then) He’s not what I pictured.
Yeah, Steve was a real normal. Judy gets choked up.
Handsome though.
Yeah. I thought he had a JFK Jr. vibe when we met.
Oh, JFK Jr. So hot.
So hot.
Then so sad.
So sad. That death seemed like really? That family hasn’t been through enough?
Seriously. And you gotta take down the wife and the sister? Jen yawns again.
You’ re tired.
I think I am. You’re not?
Not really, but I’11 let you go.
No. (beat) Would you mind... would you mind just waiting ‘til I fall asleep?
Oh. Okay. 22. 3/20/18  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 23. 3/20/18
Like all the way asleep.
Yeah, yeah, of course.
Thanks. A beat.
Should I keep talk --
No, because then I won’t be able to fall asleep.
Right. Judy stays on the phone, as Jen drifts off to sleep.
As “Don’t Worry Baby” by The Beach Boys plays, we see: INT. JEN’S BEDROOM - MORNING -Jen wakes up with her phone next to her on the pillow.

-Jen drives, sizing up different houses. -Jen approaches an OLDER MAN watering his giant lawn. She hands him her card. INT. JUDY’S NEWPORT BEACH HOUSE - DAY -Judy walks out of a huge walk-in closet, smelling one of fiancé’s shirts. She lays down on the bed and spoons it.

-Judy sits on a bench, alone, eating a salad. A YOUNG MOT pushing an ADORABLE BABY in a stroller, sits beside her. makes a silly face at the baby, and it smiles. The young mother looks at Judy, a little weirded out.
-Judy buys a bunch of weed and a can of peanuts.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 24, 3/20/18
-Jen drives, checking out every car parked on the street. -Jen pulls over, gets out and walks up to a car with aden front bumper. She writes down the license plate number.

-Judy nonchalantly hands Abe a can of peanuts. He opens t lid, peaks inside and smiles. END MONTAGE. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM / JUDY’S BEDROOM - A FEW NIGHTS LATER Jen lies in bed, sipping a glass of wine, on the phone wi Judy, who lights incense on a small table decorated with crystals, feathers and a deck of Affirmation Cards. Her T flickers in the background.
Oh my god, yes!
Right? If I knew it was over, I would start smoking immediately.
Immediately. Smoking is the greatest thing that slowly kills you.
The greatest. A beat.
Ooo, Facts of Life is on.
What channel?
Jen grabs the remote and finds the channel.
I loved this show.
Loved it.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 25. 3/20/18 They watch for a moment.
It’s not holding up.
No. (then) Wait. I don’t remember. How small was this school? Was it just the five of them?
No, they live in a dorm together and they’re friends. These very different girls who would never be friends. Jen takes a sip of wine.

INT. JUDY’S BEDROOM / JEN’S BEDROOM - A FEW NIGHTS LATER CLOSE ON Judy as she takes a sip of wine. We WIDEN TO REV she’s now in a fresh pair of pajamas. We intercut with Je who’s in another pair of her husband’s pajamas. They watc different episode of “Facts of Life.”
(re: Facts of Life) How did I not know this was on every night? More importantly, why are the other girls fifteen but Tootie is like nine?
(laughs) I don’t know. But has anyone ever told you you’re kind of a Blair?
What?! Fuck you. I’m a Jo.
You sure? Cause I’ve known you for like two weeks, so I feel like I would know.
I’m a Jo!
Okay!  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 26. 3/20/18
Why? Who are you?
I’m a Tootie. It’s layered. How are you a Jo?
I’m tough. I’m from Brooklyn.
Brooklyn? How did I not know that? You don’t sound like you’re from Brooklyn.
I used to have an accent.
What’d you sound like?
Like someone with a Brooklyn accent.
Like how?
(reluctantly does Brooklyn accent) Like dis.
(laughs) That’s fantastic.
(laughs) I hate you.

Judy enters with two Starbucks coffees and hands one to J Jen smiles. They take their seats next to each other in t circle as Pastor Wayne starts the group. INT. HENRY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Jen lays wide awake next to Henry. She checks to make sur he’s asleep. She pokes him a little. He doesn’t budge. INT. JEN’S BEDROOM - NEXT NIGHT Jen gets into bed and dials her phone.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 27. 3/20/18 INT. JEN’S FOYER - A LITTLE LATER Judy stands at the door holding a bottle of wine in one h She pulls her other arm from behind her back to reveal a second bottle of wine. EXT. JEN’S BACKYARD - A LITTLE LATER Jen and Judy sit at the edge of the pool, drinking wine, their feet dangling in the water. It’s a bougie backyard, kind with an outdoor couch and a guesthouse.
(laughs) Oh wow.
Yeah. Christopher thinks he means well but he just consistently says the exact wrong thing.
So you had to throw a decorative end table at him?
Yeah. And then he gave me an ultimatum -- grief group or anger management. And I’m very attached to my anger.
I like your anger. I admire it.
That's because you haven't been on the receiving end of it.
I mean, there may be a healthier way you can channel it. Like meditation or --
Please.
You didn’t let me finish. Or murder.
I meditate. In my own way.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 28. 3/20/18 INT. JEN’S VOLVO - MOMENTS LATER Jen and Judy sit in the car as Caliban’s “Paralyzed” blas Jen screams along to every word.
Judy is stunned, a little scared and kind of delighted. INT. JEN’S VOLVO - LATER Jen and Judy speed down Coast Highway, still listening to Caliban. Judy is trying, and failing, to get into the mus
Judy watches as Jen inspects a car with a dent in the fro bumper.
Do you do this a lot?
No, just every time I see a car witha person-sized dent in the front bumper.
(trying not to judge) Okay.
The cops keep saying hit and runs are almost impossible to solve.
But you feel like maybe you can find the person this way?

No. Jen writes down the license plate number.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 29. 3/20/18 INT. JEN’S VOLVO - A LITTLE LATER Jen and Judy have the windows down, Caliban still blastin Out the window we see Jen and Christopher’s ad on a bus bench. Jen gives the ad the finger as she races past it.
(shouting over the music I have an idea.
Jen and Judy stand at the edge of a dramatic scenic cliff They both let out primal screams into the valley, as thei screams echo back.
Jen and Judy sit on the sand.
I haven’t been to the beach at night in so long.
I love it. I really wanted to get aplace on the water. Just a condo. Just to hear the waves. But Steve wanted a salt water pool.
(re: ocean) What the fuck did he think this was?
(laughs) I know. Judy pulls out a joint and lights it.
What are you doing?
It’s legal. Relax. She offers a puff to Jen.
No, no -- I’m not a drugs person.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 30. 3/20/18
It’s not drugs, it’s a plant. It’1l help you sleep. Judy hands it to her. Jen reluctantly takes a puff, but s clearly comfortable handling a joint. JUDY (CONT’D) You totally smoke pot.
I did. With Ted, but it’s been years.
Well, I’m happy to reacquaint you.
(re: the pot) Oh, you feel, like, immediately nice.
(laughs) Yeah.
Hey. I hope this isn’t weird, but --
That’s my line.
But thank you.
For what?

For just, I don’t know, showing up in my life. Like a weird little pot fairy. And for not saying and doing the same stupid shit that everyone says and does that makes you feel more alone than you already do. And for not being repulsed by... my version of grief.
(touched) Thank you. For the same. It’s a really nice moment. A friendship sealed.
Wow, one puff and you get all mushy.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 31. 3/20/18
Alright, alright. INT. JEN’S CAR / JUDY’S BEDROOM - NEXT NIGHT The phone rings through Jen’s Bluetooth. We intercut as J picks up.
Good evening.
Good evening.
(putting her shoes on) Shall I head over?
No, because I’m coming to you.
What?
You've been coming to me for weeks.
You don’t even know where I live. Jen looks at her phone. She ZOOMS IN on the photo of Stev standing in front of their house. The house number is rig behind him.
Yeah I do.

Jen pulls up to the matching house. She gets out, a box o donuts in hand. She knocks on the door. No answer. She kn again. The door opens. A man stands there in his robe. Je immediately recognizes him. It’s STEVE.
Can I help you?
(floored) Steve?
Yeah.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 32. 3/20/18
You're... alive.
(confused) Yeah. It’s eleven-thirty. What is happening? Do I know you?
No, but I know Judy. Jen’s phone rings. She looks. It’s Judy calling.
Judy doesn’t live here anymore.
She doesn’t?
Not since we broke up three months ago. And if you see her, tell her to stop coming here when I’m at work or I’mgonna change the locks.
I’m so -- I’m sorry to bother you.
Goodnight. Steve starts to shut the door. Jen stops him. She takes something out of her purse and hands it to him.

Maybe it’s better if she doesn’t know where you live. (then) It’s a seller’s market. Steve looks at her business card and back at her, not kno what to make of any of it. INT. JUDY’S ROOM - SAME Judy paces and frantically calls Jen again. Her voicemail picks up.
Jen, I can explain. (breaking down) Please call me. I’m so sorry. Please let me explain.  DEAD TO ME "Pilot" 33. 3/20/18
Jen charges in, just as the group takes their seats in th circle. Jen heads right for Judy.
What the fuck?
What’s going on?
Jen, please.
Why don’t you tell them what’s going on, Judy?
(to Wendy) I guess Kate and Allie are having trouble.
I can explain.
